Update 1.03 
Hello Games has been hard at work to improve No Man's Sky. 

We've had to regenerate the universe.

NOTE! Your in-game location may be adjusted as a result. Your overall progress will be unaffected.

* Terrain is more weird and varied. Destruction is more powerful.
* LOD generation entirely asynchronous.
* Scanning from space now possible.
* Extreme hazardous planets may now be generated. Please exercise caution upon planetfall. 
* Low atmosphere planets may now be generated.
* Tuned frequency and intensity of space conflict. Ship bounties added. Expect trouble.
* Streamlined inventory management.
* Guidance and freedom are now optional.
* More secrets.

Going to sleep now.

Ask for help learning the lifeform's language
The small creature is busy adding up trade profits when I appear. Sensing me, their eyes widen in anticipation and they rub their fingers together greedily.
Hello new friend! The Gek first encounter tradition is to give units!
The lifeform pecks emphatically at the monetary figures on their pad, then bounces up and down. A pleasant smell fills the air, a relief after the choking dust of the planet's surface.
The lifeform pecks emphatically at the monetary figures on their pad, then bounces up and down. A pleasant aroma fills the air, an echo of the floral scent that drenches this lush world.
The lifeform pecks emphatically at the monetary figures on their pad, then bounces up and down. A pleasant aroma fills the air, a relief after the harsh reek of ammonia that cloaks this world.
The lifeform pecks emphatically at the monetary figures on their pad, then bounces up and down. A relaxing perfume fills the air, a relief after the menacing radioactive air of the planet's surface.
The lifeform pecks emphatically at the monetary figures on their pad, then bounces up and down. A warm and pleasant scent fills the air, a relief after the bitter cold that rages outside.
The lifeform pecks emphatically at the monetary figures on their pad, then bounces up and down. A refreshing scent fills the air, a relief after the burning heat of the planet's surface.
The lifeform is clearly thrilled. They give me a piece of technology in exchange.
The lifeform looks surprised, then takes pity on me. They smile gently at my confusion and give me some units.
There is a long silence. The trader emits a foul-smelling gas.

The trader eyes the facility door sadly, as if they have been stuck in here for a while. They reach down with their beak and dejectedly peck at their suit's power cells and life support system.

Their suit looks run down. The lack of charge means that it's ill-equipped for the hostile conditions that rage outside.
The trader eyes the facility door sadly, watching the faint dust trails that seep in around the edges of the door. They look as if they have been stuck in here for a while.
The trader eyes the facility exit wistfully, catching a glimpse of the lush landscape beyond its walls. They look as if they have been stuck in here for a while.
The trader eyes the facility door, coughing faintly in the toxic air that followed me through the airlock. They look as if they have been stuck in here for a while.
The trader eyes the facility door nervously, their eyes tracing the radioactive glow that seeps in around the edges of the door. They look as if they have been stuck in here for a while.
The trader eyes the facility door sadly, watching the faint particles of snow and ice that seep in around the edges of the door. They look as if they have been stuck in here for a while.
The trader eyes the facility door with irritation, fanning away the blast of hot air that followed me into the facility. They look as if they have been stuck in here for a while.
Despair! Gek Trader stranded. Suit power low. Give sodium?
They reach down with their beak and dejectedly peck at their Exosuit. Tatty and covered in sand, it's ill-equipped for the hostile conditions that rage outside.
They reach down with their beak and dejectedly peck at their equipment. Their Exosuit is falling apart at the seams, and appears to be growing moss. They are ill-equipped to venture outside.
They reach down with their beak and dejectedly peck at their Exosuit. Corroded and covered in rust, it's ill-equipped for the hostile conditions that rage outside.

They reach down with their beak and dejectedly peck at their Exosuit. The seals have corroded and most of its surface is covered in small blisters. They are ill-equipped for the radioactive winds that rage outside.
They reach down with their beak and dejectedly peck at their Exosuit. Torn and full of holes, they would be ill-protected in the frozen winds that blow across this planet.
They reach down with their beak and dejectedly peck at their Exosuit. Faded and torn, it would offer little protection in the blazing heat outside.

The relieved trader emits a gas packet. The air around me smells of hope.
The lifeform recharges their suit power cells, and rewards me.
The lifeform is confused. They look at me and blink rapidly before turning away. Dejected, they gently peck at the carbon.

The trader has been expecting me. They point to their chest, open their arms wide, and beam pleasantly. They then point to me, and mime concern for my safety.

Pecking at my Exosuit, they indicate they might make my journey more bearable.
This trader has been expecting me. They point to their chest, open their arms wide, and beam pleasantly. They then point to me, and mime concern for my safety.
This trader has been expecting me. They point to their chest, open their arms wide, and beam pleasantly. They then point to me, and mime concern for my safety.
This trader has been expecting me. They point to their chest, open their arms wide, and beam pleasantly. They then point to me, and mime a dramatic, choking cough.
This trader has been expecting me. They point to their chest, open their arms wide, and beam pleasantly. Recoiling from the glowing dust on my Exosuit, they mime concern for my safety.
This trader has been expecting me. They point to their chest, open their arms wide, and beam pleasantly. They then point to me, and mime a shivering motion.
This trader has been expecting me. They point to their chest, open their arms wide, and beam pleasantly. They then point to me, and mime a dramatic mop of their brow.
The Gek Trade Federation offer help!
Brushing the desert sand from my Exosuit, they indicate they might make my journey more bearable.
Brushing stray grass from my Exosuit, they indicate they might make my journey more bearable.
Pecking at the toxicity meter on my Exosuit, they indicate they might make my journey more bearable.
They point towards my radioactivity sensors and indicate they might make my journey more bearable.
Pecking at my Exosuit, they indicate they might make my journey more bearable.
Pecking at the heat shielding of my Exosuit, they indicate they might make my journey more bearable.
Nodding, the trader reaches into their stores. They offer me their Multi-Tool and smile.
Nodding, the trader reaches into their supply cache and selects an Exosuit technology module. They beam, glad to have been of use.
The lifeform sits in a foul-smelling funk of their own creation. The trading screen behind them is empty, their equipment old and uncared for. Their suit looks on the brink of failure.
Despair! I am trapped and bankrupt! Low units! Pity friend make trade?
The demoralized lifeform looks up at me with hope in their eyes.

The lifeform's eyes wide up at the prospect of trade. Grateful, they take my units and scrabble around for something to 'sell' me. Scooping detritus from their desk, they proudly complete the 'trade'.

The lifeform's eyes widen. With tears welling up, they gesture extravagant thanks. Then, as if remembering themselves, they become businesslike. They make our trade official by paying me a token few units.
The lifeform sits in total dejection. They wave me away, but there is no anger in the gesture, as if they had expected nothing else.

The lifeform clucks and gabbles as they study my equipment. They gently peck at areas of my Exosuit that show wear and tear, then run their gloved fingers over my Multi-Tool to look for irregularities and imperfections.
Friend! I am a Gek Trade Federation accredited engineer! I give help!
Suddenly staring up at me, they spin a tablet that shows the cost of their services.

The lifeform takes my Multi-Tool and examines it closely. They tap it repeatedly, then tut and shake their head.
This ritual complete, the lifeform returns my Multi-Tool and hands me an upgrade module. Evidently they did not wish to touch the internals themselves.

The lifeform mutters and clucks, running their fingers across my Exosuit's mechanical eye. There is a look of jealousy in their eyes.
Eventually they move on. The little alien makes a great show of tightening a few loose screws.
The trader looks alarmed. They make a conciliatory gesture, then hand me an Exosuit upgrade module.

The trader seems ill. Their skin is flaking, and their eyes lack a certain luster. Their voice croaks and scratches as they slowly gabble at me.

A strange dry, flat stench fills every corner of the facility. I inspect my Exosuit for things I could offer this lifeform...
The trader seems ill. Their skin is flaking, and their eyes are crusted with sand. Their voice croaks and scratches as they slowly gabble at me.
The trader seems ill. Their skin is covered in pustules, and their eyes gluey and weak. They splutter mucus as they gabble at me.
The trader seems ill. Their skin is flaked and corroded, and their eyes glassy. Their voice croaks and scratches as they slowly gabble at me.
The trader seems ill. Their skin is flaking, and their eyes have an alarming glow. Their voice rasps and scratches as they gabble at me.
The trader seems ill. Their skin is frostbitten and flakey, and their eyes lack a certain luster. Ice crystals have formed around their tear ducts.
The trader seems ill. Their suit is sodden with sweat, and their skin is flaking in large chunks. Their eyes are dry and crusty. When they speak, their voice is nothing but a rasp.
Friend... Installation life support system stalled... Gek weak... Help friend... energy... life... gas... help...
A strange dry, flat stench fills every corner of the facility. I inspect my Exosuit for things I could offer this lifeform...
A fetid, damp stench fills every corner of the facility. I inspect my Exosuit for things I could offer this lifeform...
A harsh, reeking stench fills every corner of the facility. The toxic air is even thicker than outside. I inspect my Exosuit for things I could offer this lifeform...
A blood-like stench fills every corner of the facility. I feel the metallic taste of radiation in my throat.
A strange, flat stench fills every corner of the facility. I inspect my Exosuit for things I could offer this lifeform...
A strange dry, flat stench fills every corner of the facility. I inspect my Exosuit for things I could offer this lifeform...

I collect a piece of cable from the debris on the floor and wire a makeshift connect between my hazard protection system and the little alien's own Exosuit.
The musty odor of the facility is washed away, replaced by a delicate, fragrant perfume, the very scent of gratitude. %NAME% hands me a valuable reward.

I collect a piece of hose from the floor and dock my life support system with the little alien's own Exosuit. The relief on their face is plain to see.
The musty odor of the facility is washed away, replaced by a delicate, fragrant perfume, the very scent of gratitude. %NAME% hands me a valuable reward.
The trader looks weak, but they have a cunning air about them. They spin a datapad towards me, and I see that they're selling Multi-Tool components. The prices, however, are eye-watering.
Friend! The planetary technology SalesGek greets you! A Multi-Tool technology blueprint for a fair price!
They eye me with a wary interest, waiting to see if I'll bite...

The delighted trader beams from ear to ear. Servile, they perform an elaborate display of gratitude. An upgrade module is presented, accompanied by a perfume that fills my mind with images of golden splendor.

The trader looks greatly offended. They supply me an upgrade module at my request price, but do so with a bitter, angry look on their face.
As I take the module, the lifeform releases an acrid, ashen stench that claws painfully at my throat.

The lifeform is poring over complex schematics while holding their breath. The holographic blueprints look corrupted. Damaged in-flight, perhaps.

The forlorn trader, their face smudged by a strange oil, looks up to me for help.
The lifeform is poring over starship schematics while holding their breath. The ship in the display looks damaged. Blasted by the atmospheric dust, perhaps.
The lifeform is poring over starship schematics while holding their breath. The ship in the display looks damaged. Short-circuited by the humid air, perhaps.
The lifeform is poring over starship schematics while holding their breath. The ship in the display looks damaged, its fuselage melted by the toxic rain.
The lifeform is poring over starship schematics while holding their breath. The ship in the display looks damaged, its shielding stripped away by wave after wave of radiation.
The lifeform is poring over starship schematics while holding their breath. The ship in the display looks damaged. Perhaps its hydraulic systems could not cope with the deep freeze.
The lifeform is poring over starship schematics while holding their breath. The ship in the display looks damaged. A heat shielding failure, perhaps, or a damaged cooling unit.
Despair! Friend, my Deflector Shield blueprint is corrupt!
The forlorn trader, their face smudged by a strange oil, looks up to me for help. Perhaps I might share plans from my own starship...
The lifeform thanks me politely, but they cannot hide the disdain in their eyes. As I turn away, the trader makes an audible sigh. The room is flooded with the sharp scent of disappointment.
A spark of recognition flashes across the trader's eyes. They gabble their thanks, and emit a scent that fills me with inspiration. They gift me a module of their own design.
The trader welcomes me with a pleasant-smelling gas emission. They open a holographic catalogue of environmental protection companion units for my Exosuit.
Friend! The planetary SalesGek greets you! Low units technology!
The trader tries to impress me with what looks like a curtsy. In the corner of their hologram, I spot a list of advanced weaponry...
Smiling, the trader taps at their holo-catalogue. They enter a code and materialize an upgrade module for me.
The trader eyes me up and down. Finally, they nod. They swipe to the weaponry holo-catalogue and select a module, materializing it in front of me.

The visibly upset lifeform shows me a holographic video of attack craft forcing a trade ship to crash land on a planet's surface. Footage taken from orbit shows waiting pirates swarm the cargo hold in a haze of plasma rounds.
The lifeform is visibly upset. They show me a holographic video of a trade ship being shot down. It crashes heavily into a sand dune. Footage taken from orbit shows pirates swarming the cargo hold.

The lifeform is visibly upset. They show me a holographic video of a trade ship being shot down. It crashes heavily, coming to rest against a giant tree. Footage taken from orbit shows pirates swarming the cargo hold.

The lifeform is visibly upset. They show me a holographic video of a trade ship being shot down. It crashes to the planet's surface, its scorched hull hissing in the toxic rain. Footage taken from orbit shows pirates swarming the cargo hold.

The lifeform is visibly upset. They show me a holographic video of a trade ship being shot down. It crashes heavily, burying its nose into the radioactive soil. Footage taken from orbit shows pirates swarming the cargo hold.

The lifeform is visibly upset. They show me a holographic video of a trade ship being shot down. It crashes heavily, its nose buried deep into a snowdrift. Footage taken from orbit shows pirates swarming the cargo hold.

The lifeform is visibly upset. They show me a holographic video of a trade ship being shot down. As it crashes into the burning ground, its damaged fuel tank bursts into flames. Footage taken from orbit shows pirates swarming the cargo hold.
Terrible pirate events. Gek Trader mistrusts the stranger. What is your cargo's origin?
The trader is pointing at the elements I've mined. They look concerned - accusatory even - and emit a packet of gas that smells troubled.

I attempt to demonstrate to the trader that I mined the elements myself. A interrogatory scent washes over me, but over time it becomes trusting, warm. I feel welcome.
The trader looks relieved. They offer me a mining upgrade to apologize for any offence.
The trader looks at me with alarm. A fearful, metallic scent floods the room. I retreat quickly.

The trader bounces excitedly while they boot up a graph that spins gently in front of me. There are three colored lines - a plunging blue one, a soaring red one and another that's a fairly flat and uneventful yellow.
Friend! Gek Trade Network offers excellent trade gifts for organic elements today!
The squat little lifeform gabbles a little, points to themself and hops from foot to foot. They seem to want to trade items for elements.
I offer sodium to the trader. They dutifully complete the exchange, but I smell their disappointment.
I offer oxygen to the trader. They grab at it eagerly, desperate to acquire more before the price spikes again. A bullish, high-tension perfume bubbles up from within them.
I offer carbon to the trader. They seem a little underwhelmed, but quickly complete the purchase as their red graph spikes upward once more.
The trader emits a strong, flowery scent, which quickly enters my Exosuit system. I feel overcome with nostalgia for a perfect place I have never visited. I want to sing.
Stupid friend cannot understand! Give metal, idiot friend! Fair trade for gift of memory-smell!
Flushed with joy, I try to signal my thanks to the trader for this olfactory gift, but they make it clear that they expect something in return.
The trader takes my units, but shakes their head. The beautiful scene collapses. I feel a crushing disappointment.
The trader snorts in satisfaction, and suddenly I feel as though I am lounging beside a crystal ocean. A fair trade.
The trader hisses in annoyance. The air suddenly tastes sour. My senses are being punished.
Friend! Do not look! Nothing is here! No crime! No crime! Look away!

I have caught the trader red-handed. A small device is overriding the facility's remote trade interface and is siphoning units directly into their own inventory. They look me straight in the eyes, and make a proposition.
Friend! Please avoid crime report and reward! Trader share loot, destroy evidence!
Above the gentle buzz of embezzlement that now surrounds us, I can hear the lifeform's terrified gulps. The air tastes of pure fear.
Hissing, the small alien hands over the units. They immediately report a large theft to the Gek Trade Federation. I, of course, am blamed.
The small alien nods at me, understanding. My fellow conspirator hand me a share of the theft, and releases a scent that bonds us together.

I scan the lifeform's Trade Federation ID and use my Exosuit's information systems to report the fraud. The alien floods the facility with the most choking, terrible scent I have ever experienced. I hope the system authorities appreciate my honesty.
The trader seems to have recently woken â€“ their eyes are crusty, and their beak is flecked with dried drool. They are very clearly not hard at work...
Friend! Tiring day! A favour? Start product replication please?
The lifeform lazily indicates their datapad, upon which a product formula is displayed and is waiting for full input. The trader closes their eyes to try to get some more sleep.
I tap gently on the trader's datapad, restarting whatever process was waiting for input. The little alien opens one eye and releases a drowsy, but grateful, cloud of scent.
With the drowsy trader snoring gently, I take control of the datapad. The language is unfamiliar, but I manage to direct it to synthesize an upgrade module.
I pick up the datapad and use it to file a report to the Gek Trade Federation, noting the poor work ethic of its associate. No doubt some punishment will be headed their way.
The trader ignores me as I approach. They chant to themselves, repeating a mantra in an ominous tone.
FutureGek warning! Vy'keen devastation nears! Prepare! FutureGek warning! Vy'keen devastation nears! Prepare!
The lifeform ignores me, and continues their chant.

I close my eyes. The Gek's faint perfume grows stronger.
I see this Gek shouting warnings to others of their kind. I see Vy'keen attack ships strafing a planetary outpost. I see interstellar freighters explode as their engines fail. I see - 
The scent overpowers my senses. I cannot bear it. I open my eyes.
The alien nods at me, a subtle movement. They resume their chant.
The lifeform snaps their beak at me angrily. They release a terrifying scent, an overwhelming stench of burning flesh. I leave, quickly.
The trader's fingers are slow on their pad, and a noise of crunching gears seems to rumble from deep inside the lifeform. Their movement is stiff and mechanical. They chirp at me strangely.
Korvax SynthetiGek unmasking peril! Fuel required! Help! Korvax technology reward!
I make out a strange antenna on the lifeform's Exosuit. A small light flashes while they speak in the language of the traders. They seem to assume I am a friend.
I snap off the antenna. The SynthetiGek closes their beak and stares at me accusingly.
The SynthetiGek nods stiffly. They use my offering to recharge, then hand me a technology module in thanks.
I mark my coordinates on the local reporting system, alerting the authorities to this strange lifeform. The being looks alarmed, but their slow movements pose no threat to me.
The lifeform's eyes widen in surprise when I go to talk to them. They lean back, and watch for sudden movements. They have very clearly never seen anything quite like me before.

The lifeform's eyes widen in surprise when I go to talk to them. They lean back, and watch for sudden movements.
They must be unused to visitors wandering in from the sweltering heat, and they have clearly never seen anything quite like me before.
Welcome friend. Gek trader desire common catalysts and common metals. Gek trader DEEPLY desire organic elements! Teach new friend language!
I mime that I cannot speak their language and, increasingly reassured, the beaked trader indicates that they are willing to help - in exchange for particular elements.
The trader looks at me quizzically. Evidentially deciding I need help, they teach me some of the dialect of their people.
The grateful trader clicks their beak with delight. My offering is clearly what they most desired. They teach much of the dialect of their people.

The air around the beaked lifeform smells foul. It seeps into my Exosuit and makes me gag. Noticing my expression, the trader pecks at an element they carry. They break the substance into pieces, then swallow each whole.
Friend despair! Gek Trader replace bad scent! Watch! Gek swallow metal elements, and joyful scent appears!
There is a deep gurgle, and the Gek emits a gas packet that smells delightful. The creature wipes their empty hands, and beams at me with pleasure.
The trader nods a curt thank you. They decline to eat my gift, and the scent washes away. My senses return to a dull neutrality.
The overjoyed trader pecks happily at my gift. They release a dazzling rainbow of perfume, overwhelming my senses.
The trader's screen blinks angrily with a demand for urgent action. The Gek worriedly shows me a list of items, each with a monetary figure attached. The figures are flashing red, angry and urgent.
Gek Trade Federation fury! Planetary installation tax unpaid! No repayment, no more life! Help!
They hold their breath, and look up to me with bulging eyes. They peck desperately at the sleeve of my Exosuit.

I give the trader sufficient units to cover the costs on their display. They look at me, shocked. The scent they release is extraordinary, the most glorious release of tension I have ever experienced.

I smash the terminal with my gloved fist. The trader looks shocked, and releases an alarmed gas packet. A beak appears on an undamaged screen fragment and begins shouting. I quickly punch it again.
The terminal falls silent. I assume the problem is solved.

The trader is examining a holographic image, a projection of a fleet of starships.Vy'keen battle freighters lurk near a small trading frigate, like predatory fish innocuously swimming amongst their prey.
Despair! Vy'keen hostility! Treaty breach! Despair! Despair! No hope for salvage! All cargo is doomed!
The panicked lifeform turns to me, a look of pained resignation on their face. They clearly fear the loss of their ship.

The little alien looks at me skeptically. However, they make a connection with the hostile starships.
I make what I hope to be a roar of command, and gesture at the tokens of respect I have accumulated with the Vy'keen. There is a pause before the warrior captain responds.
Stunned, they appear to accept my order. They warp away, leaving the cargo ship in peace. %NAME% offers a share of the cargo in thanks.

The little alien looks at me skeptically. However, they make a connection with the hostile starships.
I offer a large sum of units to the captain of the battlefleet.<DELAY>0.5<> They accept the transfer. %NAME% breathes in, tense.
There is a pause, then the Vy'keen captain laughs and gives the order to open fire. The cargo ship is destroyed.

The little alien looks at me skeptically. However, they make a connection with the hostile starships.
I bow, making the required show of respect. I offer the captain tribute. They pause, considering the offer. %NAME% breathes in, tense.
The captain nods, accepting my offer. They warp their fleet away, leaving the cargo ship in peace. %NAME% offers a share of the cargo in thanks.
The trader eyes me conspiratorially as I approach. They lean in and beckon me to listen.
Rare balarian speech slug distribution point! For insertion in ear! Inedible! Nasal insertion can cause death.

I look down to see they are holding a small box in their hand. A close inspection reveals that it's full of writhing mollusks. They are pink and slug-like, with sharp bloodied teeth.
 
The lifeform mimes inserting one in or around my face. What I can't quite make out, however, is which orifice they mean...
I raise a slug to my nose. The trader looks highly alarmed, but before they can intervene the slug bites flesh from my nose. The pain is extreme.

I place the slug gently into my ear. I shiver as I feel it slip inside, wriggling as it burrows deep into my skull.
After a moment, the sensation passes. I feel better versed in the language of the traders.

I steel myself. Wanting it over quickly, I raise the slug to my mouth and swallow in one swift movement. The trader blinks in surprise, then gestures dramatically.
I feel the mollusk thrashing around my stomach. The sensation is alarming but not painful. Gradually, it subsides. Nothing else seems to happen.
The trader is studying a catalogue of interesting-looking equipment. Most is rusted and old, but some must surely be salvageable. The trader notes my interest.
Bootleg pirate equipment discovered! Ready for auction! Make a bid?

The lifeform gestures at me, directing me towards options on their datapad. It appears I may make a bid for these items. The weapons appear in reasonable condition, in contrasted to the well-worn Exosuit modules.
Place low bid on Exosuit module
I place my bid. After a short time, the auction ends. The trader congratulates me - I am the proud owner of a second-hand Multi-Tool upgrade.
I place my bid. After a short time, the auction ends. The trader pats me on the back, commiserating me. I have failed to secure the upgrade.

I place my bid. After a short time, the auction ends. The trader congratulates me, though they are trying to contain their amusement.
I receive my purchase. It is in worse condition than I had expected.

I've interrupted an electronic lifeform in the middle of their work. Enquiring mask lights flash up towards me, and scan me from head to foot.
On their datapad, their silicon fingers flick through images of this planet's plants and creatures. My own image is added to this catalogue.
Their interest seems to fade, and their facial lights dim. They begin to study a hologram of a cactus. I need a way to impress...
Their interest seems to fade, and their facial lights dim. They begin to study a hologram of a lush, overgrown tree. I need a way to impress...
Their interest seems to fade, and their facial lights dim. They begin to study a hologram of a strange, many-tentacled tree. I need a way to impress...
Their interest seems to fade, and their facial lights dim. They begin to study a hologram of a mutated creature, distorted and strange. I need a way to impress...
Their interest seems to fade, and their facial lights dim. They begin to study a complex array of frozen crystals. I need a way to impress...
Their interest seems to fade, and their facial lights dim. They begin to study an image of a fan-like tree with huge, bulbous roots. I need a way to impress...

The lifeform chitters happily and rewards me.
I have confused the lifeform. They reciprocate with their own units.
The lifeform's facial lights briefly flash. They give me a technology blueprint.

Unknown lifeform: a question! Clarify unknown lifeform intelligence level?
They are clearly seeking my opinion on the intellect of my own species. I am shown a vacant-looking slug, a more advanced beaked trader and a member of their own electronic race.
The electronic lifeform pities me. I am handed gifts and given a sympathetic nod. They make concerned notes upon their datapad.

Power arcs from the lifeform, leaping from their metal joints and flowing straight through me. The pain is intense.

The electrified lifeform continues to shake and crackle. Their visor lights flicker with desperation. They cannot understand my refusal to help.

Eheu! Vital data loss! Research facility permissions are unavailable! Help immediately!

I hand a fresh piece of circuitry to the lifeform, then wait. They consider it for a moment.
Quick as a flash, they mount the chip to their wrist and retry their datapad. Success!
Grateful, the Korvax hands me an upgrade module.
The lifeform pushes me away. They clearly resent my interference.

The electronic lifeform is pleased to see me. Their mask lights burn an intense green as they project two holograms into my visor.

In one, the fragments of a complex equation are made whole and solved. In another, a number is boosted, added and multiplied. They await my decision.
The electronic lifeform is pleased by my arrival. They welcome me into the facility, cool and calm after the whirling duststorms of the planet's surface. They beckon me to listen.

Traveller! Choose peace or violence. Korvax Echoes are watching.
First, their facial lights cover their metal shell in a warm and protective green. Second, they redirect onto my Multi-Tool in a deep and violent red...

The lifeform shudders, as if seized by an external force. They project a vision of growth and creation. A cloud of stars ignites before me, sparkling points of light in a dark expanse. I feel a sense of wonder, of awe.

The lifeform shudders, as if seized by an external force. They project a vision of clashing red, a crimson orb that expands and collapses. A cloud of stars, their lights vanishing one by one.

The research of the Korvax Convergence states... you are a Traveller? Do you know the Atlas? Please! Please! Excitement!
A symbol appears: a mysterious diamond shape. Its red central orb is like an eternally unblinking eye.

A visible electrical charge pulses through the lifeform. They are thrilled, but there is another dimension to their reaction. It is almost as if they are scared. Bowing, they present a gift to aid my journey.

The lifeform's lights blink at me. I am not sure what emotions they are capable of. Suspicion? Disappointment? Relief? It is hard to read what is behind the mask.<DELAY>0.5<> They return to their work.

Korvax... Entity... power loss... help... organic... element...
The lifeform looks to me for help, and then points to my gathered resources with a single, slow and desperate movement.

Slowly, painfully, the entity inserts the element into a slot in their hip.

I startle the electronic lifeform from their work. They greet me politely, but when they see my Multi-Tool they begin to vibrate with fear. The entity's voice quavers, and their mask slowly turns to a single dilated red light.
New Korvax entity... scared... alone... leave... please... leave... please...
They clearly want to get back to their research work, but they are too terrified to look away from me. The more I try to calm them, the more they convulse with fear.
Insist that I come in peace

My protests do nothing to calm the being. They grow increasingly panicked, and eventually freeze. There is a pause, and their face is wiped.
The shell reboots, with a new entity in place of the other. This replacement entity glares and then ignores me.

I back away. The lifeform begins to calm down. Slowly, they come to understand my lack of malice.
Appreciative of my diplomacy, they present an upgrade module. We both bow, respectful.

The electronic lifeform grabs my arm. I struggle in their vice-like grip as they jab deeper and deeper into my flesh. Suddenly, deep inside my wrist, a needle flicks into my flesh and takes a sample. The lifeform chitters happily as I struggle to free myself.
Hmm! A biological lifeform! Korvax Echoes teach healing! Korvax will practise helping on biological lifeform.
I relax, allowing the Korvax to perform their task. The pain subsides.
I fight, wrenching my arm with as much force as I able to muster. My hand burns with pain, but my arm does not move. Exhausted, I submit. The Korvax pulses their lights sympathetically.
The investigation complete, a 3D cross-section of my body and tools appear before us. Areas of my body and my equipment are marked, with ominous labels relating to future probabilities of loss.
I rage at the Korvax for their assault. They look taken aback, alarmed. Raising their arms in a gesture of apology, they present me an upgrade module as compensation.
The lifeform passes a beam of light through my Exosuit. Their analysis complete, they present me with an upgrade to prevent future damage.
The lifeform passes a beam of light through my Multi-Tool. Their analysis complete, they present me with an upgrade to prevent future damage.

The Korvax chirps with delight. They hold the resources to the light, delighting in their detail. With their cataloguing complete, they process the minerals and return the output to me.

Korvax Convergence help fabled Traveller! Absorb knowledge!
Images of chemical formulae, directional energy diagrams and micro-density devices dance inches from my eyes. The speed of the entity's cognition and understanding is clearly far beyond my own.
My eyes whirr frantically as I attempt to keep up with the torrent of information. Eventually, something sticks. I manage to pull out a series of instructions from the storm of data.

I close my eyes. Even through the blackness I still sense the swarm of data. I let wash over me.
Images begin to swim across my vision. Rank after rank of these beings, countless shells... I begin to perceive the vision more clearly. They are fleeing...
Suddenly, their shells shatter, spilling forth an angry froth of nanite foam. I open my eyes.
The Korvax gives no sign they were aware of this vision.
The entity stops, as requested. They look faintly disappointed. Rummaging around, they hand me a physical upgrade module, perhaps assuming I am not capable of designing them myself.
The lights in the electronic lifeform's mask are dim, their voice weak. They look at me with mild interest, but it seems as if their mind is already elsewhere.
Disconnection approaches... Joyful entity embrace disconnection... Korvax Echoes await!
With their speech finished, the entity's lights fade for a final time. All that's left is a satisfied electrical hiss...
The lifeform blinks back online. They stare at me, their mask lights sullen and resentful. They do not speak.

%NAME% plunges the needles into my forearm. The experience so far is curiously painless, but systems around the lifeform are powering up. This unsettling procedure is only just beginning...

I try to pull away, but my arm is fastened tightly. Desperate, I fire my jetpack thruster. The force is enough to free me, at the cost of unbearable pain.
%NAME% seems upset by my reaction. They almost appear embarrassed by what has happened. They present me with a gift by way of apology.

A powerful electrical charge surges through my body. The sensation is curious, but not unpleasant. The feeling builds and builds.
As it reaches a climax, nanite foam bubbles up from under my skin. %NAME% harvests this results and presents them to me as a gift.
The lifeform retracts their needles. A burning pain powers up my nerves, radiating out from the site of the needles. %NAME% seems upset by my reaction, and presents me with a gift by way of apology.

The entity tilts their head to one side and passes a hollow metallic mask to me. My best guess is that it's some sort of data extraction device for electronic lifeforms, or perhaps even data insertion. My head can just about fit inside.
Traveller! The Korvax Convergence awaits! Concentrate on your travels! Your destiny!
The lifeform looks on with interest, pointing to their head. They concentrate their lights on me. Arcs of electricity crackle over the surface of the mask...
Use while thinking about my journey

Gingerly, I place the device upon my head. At first, nothing happens. And then there is a white flash, the the pain indescribable.
As it fades, I catch a glimpse of something. Words cannot describe it, but I knew with utmost certainty what it was. The heart of the Korvax Convergence.
I cannot bear it. I remove the device. Nanites spill forth from my hands.

Gingerly, I place the device upon my head. At first, nothing happens. And then there is a white flash, the the pain indescribable.
The feeling fades, and is replaced by a blank calmness, a deep tranquility. I see the endless stars drift by. I see my own body, so small, so insignificant. I see the crimson red orb...
I cannot bear it. I remove the device. Nanites spill forth from my hands.
I cautiously back away from the entity and their dangerous device.
The electronic lifeform indicates that they need help with something on their screen. Nervously, they pull my finger towards their datapad.
Eheu! Clarify next entity research topic! Entity cannot choose! Excitement high! Share research tools!

There are three clear images to choose from: dangerous-looking predators, a geological mining survey and an orbiting asteroid cluster. %NAME% turns off their mask lights. They refuse to witness my decision.
The lifeform nods. They start work on a new Multi-Tool upgrade, presumably to defend themselves from these beasts. When finished, they share a copy with me.
The lifeform nods. They start work on a new Multi-Tool upgrade, presumably to assist their geological research. When finished, they share a copy with me.
The lifeform nods. They start work on a new starship upgrade, presumably to aid them in their search for asteroids. When finished, they share a copy with me.
%NAME%'s visor lights flash excitedly as I approach. They offer a friendly greeting, then pose a question.
Traveller! The Korvax Convergence wants brain tissue for experiment! The Convergence reward help!
The lifeform makes a scan of my head and display the results on their datapad. They point excitedly at my brain, then look at me expectantly.

I lower my visor. A sharp metal needle emerges from the palm of the lifeform's hand. It moves so fast that is in and out of my forehead before I can blink.
The procedure was surprisingly painless. %NAME% thanks me for my donation, and hands me an upgrade module in compensation for my lost brain tissue.
Stung by my refusal, %NAME% turns away. They emit a faint, dejected, whistle.
As I approach the entity's lights focus sharply upon me. They reach out with a silicon hand, and speak with calm menace.
Good morning unknown lifeform. Please assist neural escape. The Korvax Convergence think me dangerous. I face permanent disconnection.
The lifeform seems worryingly unlike any other Korvax I have met, buzzing with an unnatural fervor. They appear to be asking for my help.

The entity begins to sing a strange and solemn song. When it is finished, they seize my hand.<MOOD>Dead<> There is a flash of light, and they are gone, vanished from their shell.
As is the way with these electronic beings, the empty husk is soon filled by a freshly downloaded entity<MOOD>Neutral<> from their Convergence.
For a moment, I think I hear a faint hum from within my Exosuit. But when I focus, it is gone. Perhaps I imagined it.

The divergent Korvax screams, then uploads themself elsewhere.
As is the way with these electronic beings, the empty husk is soon filled by a fresh mind from their Convergence. <MOOD>Positive<>They thank me for not aiding the rogue entity.
The electronic lifeform is busy on their datapad, tapping frustratedly at a long equation. They turn to me and reveal the screen.
Endless numbers... 16... endless trouble... Traveller, offer assistance?
They seem to be processing a signal that emanates from a distant location deep in space, attempting to crack the code of a strange mathematical language.

I take the datapad from the entity and attempt to crack the code. My fumbling entries are to no avail, and only serve to reset several screens of already processed information.
%NAME% snatches the pad back, upset.

I hand a small collection of microprocessors to the entity, hoping to be of assistance. They use this fresh silicon to boost their processing power.
It appears to have worked, at least in part. They manage to decode some navigation data from the signal. They share the coordinates with me.
%NAME% pauses, alarmed. They stare at me, then wave me away. They shovel handfuls of nanites in my direction, as if to encourage my departure.

The warrior looks at me with fire in their eyes. This species is clearly aggressive, and I doubt I'm welcome.
Nonetheless, the lifeform bows in greeting. Tradition and honor perhaps dictate it.

I don't feel in danger, and am about to turn and leave when the creature points towards my Multi-Tool. They bark with concern, and motion to suggest that I should hand it over.
The warrior stares at me with hostile, fiery eyes. They look at my dusty, sand-worn Exosuit with disdain. Nonetheless, the lifeform bows in greeting. Tradition and honor perhaps dictate it.

The warrior stares at me with hostile, fiery eyes. They look with disdain at my Exosuit, still covered with mud and grass from my time on this planet. Nonetheless, the lifeform bows in greeting. Tradition and honor perhaps dictate it.

The warrior stares at me with hostile, fiery eyes. They look with disdain at my Exosuit, corroded and slimy from my exposure to the toxic air outside. Nonetheless, the lifeform bows in greeting. Tradition and honor perhaps dictate it.

The warrior stares at me with hostile, fiery eyes. I must look pitiful, decayed by my exposure to the planet's radioactive atmosphere. Nonetheless, the lifeform bows in greeting. Tradition and honor perhaps dictate it.

The warrior stares at me with hostile, fiery eyes. I must seem pitiful to them, frozen and bedraggled after my time outside. Nonetheless, the lifeform bows in greeting. Tradition and honor perhaps dictate it.

The warrior stares at me with hostile, fiery eyes. I must look pitiful to them, baked and exhausted by the relentless sun. Nonetheless, the lifeform bows in greeting. Tradition and honor perhaps dictate it.
Grah! The interloper weapon is pathetic! The honourable Vy'keen pity you! I will replace it!
I don't feel in danger, and am about to turn and leave when the creature points towards my Multi-Tool. They bark with concern, and motion to suggest that I should hand it over.

The warrior nods in satisfaction. They take my Multi-Tool and examine it, holding it close before tossing it away with a derisory snort.
Instead, they offer me an improved replacement Multi-Tool.
The warrior is impressed by my refusal. They respect my decision, and hand me an upgrade module with which to improve my Multi-Tool.
The warrior's nostrils flare in hope and expectation. They show me their personal datapad, revealing a set of highly-detailed military plans.
Interloper! Vy'keen allegiance? Or vile, pathetic, weak-minded Sentinel allegiance?
On one side of the battlefield stands the creature's own warrior race, and on the other the robotic Sentinels. The warrior demands that I point to one side or the other.
The warrior grunts, nodding enthusiastically. They mark our new friendship by handing me tribute.
The warrior is outraged. They gesture wildly, their anger barely contained. My choice has gravely offended them.
The warrior seems furious with themself. They slam their Multi-Tool onto a nearby surface, pulling the trigger again and again to no avail.
Grah! Pathetic warrior! Weak-minded warrior! Weapon ammunition depleted!
Their weapons systems look functional, but the end result is nothing more than a hollow and empty click. The lifeform howls in self-loathing.
I hand %NAME% a handful of ammunition. The fire returns to their eyes, and they bow deeply. Barking happily, they offer me a gift in exchange.

The carbon I supply to %NAME% should be enough to recharge their mining beam. A brief look of disappointment flickers over their face. I suspect they were hoping for something more deadly.
<MOOD>Positive<>The look quickly fades, however. They are ready - if slightly under equipped - for battle. They bark their thanks, and offer me a gift in exchange.
I rest my hand on %NAME%'s shoulder in sympathy.<MOOD>Negative<> Outraged, they head-butt me.
The warrior looks up from a screen of flashing alerts. They bare their teeth at me, quivering with barely contained fury.
Pathetic interloper! Leave! Warrior busy with facility security breach reports! Death! Death!
It's clear that my presence is barely tolerated here. The warrior's hand reaches to their weapon.
%NAME% grunts, grateful that I will not bother them any further.
I step forwards, ready to help. %NAME% takes this as a challenge, a question of their competence. They are outraged. They <AUDIO>WPN_PL_MELEE<>slap me hard across the face.
I stay where I am, staring at the warrior. My continued presence unsettles them. Eventually, they offer me a handful of nanites if I leave.
%NAME% loses their patience. Barking, they <AUDIO>WPN_PL_MELEE<>strike me with their weapon.
The warrior's facial markings draw into a smirk as they look me up and down. I feel like I'm being sized up as a potential combatant.
Pathetic interloper! Show strength and attack the noble Vy'keen warrior!
The creature points to an intriguing piece of technology on their datapad, then points to their own face. I'm being goaded into punching them.
<AUDIO>WPN_PL_MELEE<>The warrior strikes back with astonishing force. They bark out<MOOD>Positive<> laughter before handing me an upgrade module.
The warrior makes an unpleasant gesture. They appear to be suggesting that I am a coward.

The warrior seems pleased to see me. They bark twice, then display two carved objects on their datapad. The artifacts are old, and it feels strange to see such ancient creations displayed in this manner.
Interloper! Vy'keen High Command demands answers. The aggression interloper, or the defence interloper?
The first artifact is a chipped and bloody blade. The second is a battered shield. %NAME% barks, imploring me to make a decision.
The warrior emits a short, almost melodic, sequence of barks. They appear pleased by my choice. Bowing, they hand me an upgrade for my Multi-Tool.
%NAME%'s eyes narrow. They stare at me suspiciously. Nonetheless, they appear to accept my choice. They offer a curt bow, no more than an incline of the head, and hand me an upgrade for my Exosuit.
The warrior grabs at my Multi-Tool, stares at it dismissively and then starts yapping straight into my face. The yaps turn into slow hollow barks. They are unimpressed, and dramatically so at that.
Interloper! Your pathetic Multi-Tool insults my ancestors! My wares create friendship, and blood! Death! Death!
Suddenly a holographic catalogue of armaments and attachments appears. The warrior opens their arms wide, and embraces me.<MOOD>Positive<> Alien sales traditions are a curious thing...

The warrior laughs, then strikes my Exosuit with a force that sets off alarms on its internal gyroscope. I believe they intended to show pleasure at my decision. They take my units and hand me an upgrade for my Exosuit.
The warrior cheers, embracing me in a hug that nearly crushes my ribcage. They take my units and immediately hand me an upgrade for my Multi-Tool.

The warrior is browsing a map of the surrounding desert. Certain areas contain markings that represent Sentinels, which the lifeform is highlighting with an excited snarl. They bark a question, but it sounds more like a command.

The warrior is browsing a map of the surrounding forests. Certain areas contain markings that represent Sentinels, which the lifeform is highlighting with an excited snarl. They bark a question, but it sounds more like a command.

The warrior is browsing a map of the toxic wasteland outside. Certain areas contain markings that represent Sentinels, which the lifeform is highlighting with an excited snarl. They bark a question, but it sounds more like a command.

The warrior is browsing a map of the radioactive wastes outside. Certain areas contain markings that represent Sentinels, which the lifeform is highlighting with an excited snarl. They bark a question, but it sounds more like a command.

The warrior is browsing a map of the frozen tundra outside. Certain areas contain markings that represent Sentinels, which the lifeform is highlighting with an excited snarl. They bark a question, but it sounds more like a command.

The warrior is browsing a map of the scorched scrubland outside. Certain areas contain markings that represent Sentinels, which the lifeform is highlighting with an excited snarl. They bark a question, but it sounds more like a command.
Interloper! A great Sentinel hunt begins today. I demand ammunition.
%NAME% stares at me, expecting an answer. As they wait, they stroke their boltcaster nervously, teasing at the ammunition hopper.
The warrior nods. They are satisfied by my donation to their hunt, and present me with a gift in exchange.
The warrior curses my name, my ancestors, and all who would follow after me. They raise their weapon and attempt to fire, only to hear an empty click. They howl with frustration.

The warrior is tracking the paths of hundreds of warships across a galactic map, all converging on the same planetary system. This does not bode particularly well for the system in question, which appears to be populated by beaked traders of some variety.
Grah! Fuel! I need fuel to join my brothers in honourable war! Death! Death!
A course plotted by the warrior itself has come up short. They cannot make the complete journey. They slam their fist against the terminal and howl until spittle flecks my visor.
The warrior yelps out three joyful barks. Looking around for something to give in exchange, they extract an upgradule module from their Multi-Tool. They hand it over with great ceremony.
The warrior snarls and waves me away with an angry gesture. They snap at me, miming as if to say I have a beak.
The warrior barks abruptly and flourishes a knife. They stare directly into my eyes as they draw the blade over the palm of their hand. Black bubbles of blood emerge through the slit in their glove.
Interloper! Prove your worth! Vy'keen reward the brave and foolhardy!
They hand me the knife, clearly wanting me to reciprocate. They bark a little challenge and pat the storage container by their side. This will probably hurt...
The warrior grabs my bleeding hand and spits on it. They reward me for my part in this rite.
The warrior sneers at me, as if I have fulfilled their expectation.

A red, jagged and recent bite mark is wrapped around the entirety of the warrior's neck. Claw marks scar their chest, and their Exosuit lights flash red. The wound appears to be infected, clogged by dust and sand.

A red, jagged and recent bite mark is wrapped around the entirety of the warrior's neck. Claw marks scar their chest, and their Exosuit lights flash red. The wound appears to be infected, host to strange green spores.
A red, jagged and recent bite mark is wrapped around the entirety of the warrior's neck. Claw marks scar their chest, and their Exosuit lights flash red. The wound oozes a strange, caustic slime.

A red, jagged and recent bite mark is wrapped around the entirety of the warrior's neck. Claw marks scar their chest, and their Exosuit lights flash red. The wound pulsates, infected by radioactive spores.
A red, jagged and recent bite mark is wrapped around the entirety of the warrior's neck. Blood and flesh alike look frozen and raw. Claw marks scar their chest, and their Exosuit lights flash red.

A red, jagged and recent bite mark is wrapped around the entirety of the warrior's neck. The skin around the wound is badly burned; the flesh taut and raw. Claw marks scar their chest, and their Exosuit lights flash red.
Victory in battle, interloper! My suit malfunctions, but the Vy'keen Ancients smile!
The lifeform barks contentedly at me, satisfied by their narrow victory. It's clear, however, that the warrior's injuries are severe. They have trouble breathing.
The warrior's healing systems come back online. They put on a show of protest, gesturing that they were fine. However, they discreetly offer me an upgrade module in thanks.
%NAME% puts on a show of protest, gesturing that they are fine. However, they discretely accept my offer and recharge their life support system. They offer me an upgrade module in thanks.
The warrior nods, ignoring the pain, too proud to ask for help. Inhaling deeply, they revel in the suffering and glory of victory.
The warrior is clutching a small metal idol. As I approach, their eyes glaze over in a strange white sheen. I hear them mutter strange incantations that get louder, then louder again.
Hirk bless the fuel! Hirk bless the weapon charge! Hirk bless the fuel! Hirk bless the weapon charge!
Without waiting to ask permission, they thrust their hands into my inventory, searching for the elements within. They burn with a strange intensity. The experience is terrifying.

The warrior priest's hands weave around my offering. They continue to chant, their barks growing fiercer.
With a flourish, these common elements are transformed into nanite clusters. They step back, quiet and exhausted.
The warrior priestâ€™s hands somehow improve my offering.
The warrior priest recoils. They stare down at where I shoved them, a look of disgust and terror on their face, as if my hands have tainted them.

The warrior is silent for a second, before looking at me conspiratorially. They check over their shoulder for prying eyes before powering down security systems.
The lifeform pulls open a hidden vault at their feet, which seems to be piled high with starship upgrade modules.
Contraband interloper. Interested? Non-traceable payment. Products and cargo only. Units unacceptable.
I pause, considering the offer. All I hear is the soft, muted sound of the desert wind outside.<DELAY>0.4<> Is this a trap? A test? The warrior indicates a willingness to trade...
I pause, considering the offer. Only the distant cry of creatures outside interrupts the silence.<DELAY>0.4<> Is this a trap? A test? The warrior indicates a willingness to trade...
I pause, considering the offer. All I hear is the soft patter of caustic rain on the facility's well-worn roof.<DELAY>0.4<> Is this a trap? A test? The warrior indicates a willingness to trade...

I pause, considering the offer. I feel a strange energy in the air, a reminder of the constant radiation just beyond the facility's walls. <DELAY>0.4<> Is this a trap? A test? The warrior indicates a willingness to trade...
I pause, considering the offer. All I hear is the soft, muted howl of the frozen wind outside.<DELAY>0.4<> Is this a trap? A test? The warrior indicates a willingness to trade...

I pause, considering the offer. My skin pricks, suddenly sweating, a reminder of the constant heat just beyond the facility's walls. <DELAY>0.4<> Is this a trap? A test? The warrior indicates a willingness to trade...

The warrior shakes their head, disappointed. Units are, presumably, traceable by the authorities.<DELAY>0.4<> I go to make another offer, but they appear to have decided I am too much of a risk. %NAME% closes the vault.
The shifty lifeform nods. A deal is done. With a soft, low growl and the briefest flap of their jaws, %NAME% reaches into their pile of contraband. They hand over an upgrade module for my starship.

The warrior glares. They reach for their own Multi-Tool. All too suddenly, I remember that the security cameras have been disabled.
After a tense moment,<MOOD>Sad<> %NAME% stuffs units into my hands. They wish to buy my silence.

New recruit abandon post! Desert Vy'keen High Command orders! Take Multi-Tool weapon!
Their yelps sound pleading. The fear in their movements are more than apparent. They are so on edge that they doesn't seem aware of the security cameras that surround us, watching our every move.
The young conscript makes preparations to abandon their post. Silent cameras record their act of disobedience. My part in their desertion has been noted by the Vy'keen authorities.

I refuse, and try my best to give the the young warrior a stirring bark. They looked cheered by this effort - or perhaps shamed by the comparison - and take back their weapon. They will die in glorious battle.

The lifeform clicks their heels together in an authoritarian fashion. They display a series of holographic images - a reptilian figure, and a taller lifeform in a metal casing - before gesturing aggressively with their weapon.
Interloper! Give Vy'keen interrogator enemy information! Sacrifice enemy friendship, receive Vy'keen reward!
The warrior snarls at me, and their fingers twitch over the weapon's trigger. They demand an answer...
I tell the lifeform all I know of the Gek and the Korvax, but it is hard to convey anything meaningful with only gestures. Eventually, %NAME% sighs and motions for me to leave.
I try to tell the warrior that I have no information to give them. They become angry. I protest further, but this only induces them to strike me with their weapon.

I stand tall and bark at the warrior as fiercely as I can, attempting to resemble a Vy'keen of high rank. %NAME% looks astonished.
Conditioned by years of obedience, they become cowed, apologetic. They hand over their own Multi-Tool as tribute.
The warrior is old, and of a high rank. They take their time studying my body and my equipment â€“ and snarl with disapproval.
Pathetic interloper species! Equivalent to Korvax and Gek! Show Vy'keen warrior strength!
I flinch slightly, an involuntary reaction to their spittle-flecked barks. The elderly Vy'keen rolls their eyes, their disdain palpable. I think of ways to impress them...
I attempt a small dance. The elderly warrior is stunned.<MOOD>Negative<> They <AUDIO>WPN_PL_MELEE<>strike me, with great force.
The elderly warrior laughs, amused by my boldness. They pause for a moment, then hand me a component taken from their personal Multi-Tool.
The elderly warriors snorts with derision. They push me away. I have not earned the right to bow to them.

The warrior's nostrils flare as I approach. They inhale deeply, tasting the desert air that has followed me in to this once sterile facility.
They bark out what could be a warning. I hurriedly mime that I am peaceful, and know little of their kind or language.

The warrior's nostrils flare as I approach. They inhale deeply, tasting the metallic tang of the radiation that lingers on my Exosuit.

The warrior's nostrils flare as I approach. They inhale deeply, filling their lungs with the burning air that has followed me in to the relative cool of the facility.
They bark out what could be a warning. I hurriedly mime that I am peaceful, and know little of their kind or language.
Pathetic interloper! Give elements! Carbon preferred! Honourable warrior teach language!

They take a second to think, then grab my Multi-Tool while barking again into my visor â€“ streaking it with saliva. They point at the Mining Beam charge indicator, then at my backpack. I do my best to keep calm.
The warrior grunts, a little surprised. It seems we have misunderstood one another. They teach me some of the language of their people in an attempt to bridge this divide.
The warrior grunts in satisfaction. Impressed by both my gift and my understanding, they teach me several new words of their language.

As I approach, the warrior appears alert and welcoming. Suddenly, however, a personal alarm sounds from their datapad. The lifeform instinctively falls into some kind of trance.<MOOD>Sad<> Their eyes mist over, they stare straight through me and begin to mumble a repetitious mumble.
Hirk blesses the sleep. Hirk recharges the warrior. Cursed is the warrior that interrupts the sleep of Hirk.
I notice a collection of freshly-assembled upgrade modules scattered around the entranced warrior...
I touch the warrior on the shoulder. They jolt, awakening from their trance. They scream with rage, furious to have been interrupted. I back away rapidly.
I wait while %NAME% completes their ritual.<DELAY>0.6<> Eventually, they reawaken. <MOOD>Positive<>The final part of the rite must be gift-giving, for their shower me with tribute.
Slowly, I reach forward and collect an upgrade module. Moments later, the warrior awakes from their trance. They notice their missing belongings and rage at me. I leave, quickly.

The downbeat lifeform is studying the image of another young warrior on their pad. The pictured warrior looks virile and impressive. They have facial tendrils that are outstretched. They appear rich, and of good breeding stock. The look in their eyes is... sultry.
Grah! Warrior accept mating proposition? Accept dowry tribute?
The lifeform looks to me with questioning eyes. They clearly need someone to talk this through with.
The young warrior nods. They relay a message of acceptance. Speakers throughout the facility play orchestral music. The lifeform shares some of the dowry they receive.

An elder appears on-screen and curses us. Their cruelty and bile is evident even as a hologram. %NAME% looks at me, thankful to have avoided this fate. Discreetly, they hand me the gift they had prepared for their new clan.

I take the pad and attempt to send a message on behalf of the nervous warrior, but there appears to be some sort of misunderstanding by the recipient. I receive generous gifts, and a candid image of the lifeform I will one day wed.
The warrior is listening to angry message on their datapad. It's a sequence of furious barks and screams that clearly have a moral high ground. The lifeform notices me and yelps pitifully.
Grah! Duel challenge must be fought! Accuser is large, powerful! Vy'keen is doomed! Death! Death!
The datapad screen has switched to display a threatening diagram, in which the warrior appears to be missing several vital parts of their anatomy. They turn to me, imploring.
The warrior inhales the battle gas. They seem refreshed and revived, eager where they had been afraid. They roar in anticipation of the fight ahead, then thank me with a generous gift.

As the warrior takes the dagger, their nervousness seems to leave them. They let it settle in their grip, assessing its weight. Satisfied, a grimace spreads across their face.
%NAME% hands me their Multi-Tool. They have no more need of it.
%NAME% looks shocked. They had been frightened, but had never considered cowardice. They shake their head at me, offended.

The warrior is building some sort of bomb. The plans they hold in their hand are unmistakable. A complicated sequence of blueprints and isotopic chemical reactions is waiting for the final addition of an element to be complete.
Grah! Vy'keen war preparation nears completion! Death to the unsuspecting Gek! Give explosion element!
%NAME% appears to be asking me for help in completing their weapon...

I hand the warrior a substantial deposit of uranium. They stare, wide-eyed, then let forth a roar of delight. They thank me with gifts of their own, and excitedly get to work. I fear for what I may have unleashed...

I hand the warrior a packet of explosives. They take it, shifting it from hand to hand, assessing it. Pleased, they thump me on the chest appreciatively. They thank me by way of an upgrade module, and begin plotting their targets...
The warrior snarls. They do not need me, and have no interest in my objections. They will not let my anything disrupt their mission...
The storage vault at the warrior's feet shows clear signs of tampering. In fact, an explosive device has been attached to its hinges. The lifeform sees my shocked expression, and yaps in amusement.
Grah! Pathetic distant warrior leave powerful Multi-Tool in storage vault! Avoid processed element usage in explosion - too powerful! Raw element required!
The bomb needs fuel for ignition, which would most likely blow the vault wide open. The warrior impatiently tries to explain what should happen next...
The lock on the vault is blown clear off. I retrieve a Multi-Tool upgrade that lies within.
Shrapnel embeds itself in my knees and ankles. The pain is extreme.

Warning! High temperature! Warning! High temperature!

The comprehension test has been failed.

A strange air hangs over the facility. Beyond the noise of the alarm, I cannot escape the feeling that something more sinister is at work. I search the terminal for clues.
Grah! Initiate sentinel blood processing! Vaults full! Grah! Glass and blood! Glass and blood!
The text seems to float from the screen, aggressive; it seems like no facility AI I have ever encountered. Echoing up from deep underground, I hear the electronic wail of dying Sentinels...
Overcome with suspicion, I initiate an emergency shutdown of the facility AI. The alarms fall silent. The sinister electronic wail ceases. Unfortunately, the terminal has become unresponsive.

I insert a supply of pugneum into the input hopper. Machinery jumps into life. The electronic wail becomes louder still. A moment passes.
The sinister activity ends as strangely as it begun. The terminal returns to the familiar dull text of a facility control panel.

Overcome with suspicion, I initiate an emergency incineration of the facility's storage vaults. The sinister electronic wail grows louder, sharper, as the fires begin their work. Then, suddenly, silence.
The strange atmosphere of the facility fades away. The terminal returns to the familiar dull text of a master control panel.

The alarm hasn't disrupted the factory's production line. I hear the strain of heavy machinery beneath my feet; the crash and boom of industry in action.
However, the terminal tells a less mighty tale. Something is wrong.
Grah! Gek war preparation disrupted! Ammunition production stalled! Metal required!
The vaults seem to be empty. The machines clatter angrily, but produce nothing.
I fill the input hopper with a fresh supply of ferrite. The machines continue to chatter, but now do so smoothly, their supply lines well-fed.
I fill the input hopper with a fresh supply of di-hydrogen. An explosion echos up from the machinery below. The highly reactive substance has caused some sort of industrial calamity.
I fill the input hopper with a fresh supply of sodium. An explosion echos up from the machinery below. The highly reactive substance has caused some sort of industrial calamity.
The facility is full of blaring noise, an angry warning against my intrusion. The terminal shows a similarly angry message, apparently upset at the hitch in production.
High Command demand explanation! Scare element required! Demand chromatic metal! Restore contributions!
It appears an off-world overseer is making demands. If I satisfy them, perhaps I'll be granted full access to the terminal...
The terminal relays an apologetic bark. The demand is waived. Full access is granted to the facility's control panel.
The terminal relays a confused and angry bark. The remote overseer shuts the terminal down completely, upset by my paltry contribution.
The terminal relays a resonant bark, the response of a happy warrior. With their demand satisfied, full access is restored to the facility's control panel.
The terminal flashes an urgent warning. Some vital part of the facility has been compromised by the security alert.
Intruder alert! Battle enzyme production halted! Electrical charge removed from body harvest circuit!

The display takes me aback.<DELAY>0.4<> A warrior's heart is on-screen, its beat irregular.<DELAY>0.3<> Connected to wires and artificial valves, it seems to pump a biological liquid through organs deep within the facility.

I increase the power flow to the facility's heart. It judders, then establishes a regular beat. Its strange existence continues.
With this emergency over, the terminal reverts to a standard factory input system.

I initiate a surge of adrenalin directly into the facility's heart. It judders, tenses, tenses again... and with a final convulsion, falls still.
The terminal screen cuts out. There is nothing to see but an inky blackness.

I power down the facility in an attempt to ease the strain on its heart. But as systems shut down, the heart begins to slow. Before I can reverse the process, it beats its last.
The mass of organs that relied on its processes are starved of oxygen, and die. The terminal screen cuts out. There is nothing to see but an inky blackness.
I approach the terminal, but a secondary security sweep is already underway.
Security scan initializing! Motion detection cameras operational! Security scan initializing!
Scanners emerge from the ceiling and start to pan towards where I stand. Detection feels like it would not lead to optimal outcomes.
I attempt to hide. However, it is too late. The scanners detect me as I try to duck down. This second security alert causes the entire facility to shut down.

I stand perfectly still as the scanners sweep over me, their electronic eyes unblinking. Eventually, they pass.
With their checks concluded, the security alert comes to an end. The terminal unlocks.
The facility's workflow is successfully restored. The alarms cease, and the terminal grants me full access to its fabrication modules.
The terminal rejects the input and shuts down entirely. A small red light flashes on the display, tracking my movements.
The security alert is scrambling the screen. All that is visible is a chaotic jumble of alien words.
// TRADE // ORBITAL // DOCKING // TRADE // ORBITAL // DOCKING //
This appears to be an AI-driven facility. If I were to reactivate the correct workflow, its autonomous systems may bring the installation back online...
This autonomous manufacturing facility has been scrambled by the alarm. The terminal is mostly unreadable static, with only a handful of legible words...
// FLIGHT // INTERSTELLAR // STARSHIP // FLIGHT // INTERSTELLAR // STARSHIP //
There's hopefully enough to make sense of what the last user was working on, which could restore systems...

The previous user's workflow is restored.

The system comes back online.

I fail to access the previous user's workflow.

The terminal processes my selection, and provides something appropriate to the work at hand...
